title: Unix/Linux
text:
File Naming conventions
 https://rafalab.dfci.harvard.edu/dsbook-part-1/productivity/unix.html

Name your files in a way that is related to their contents and specifies how they relate to other files.
The Smithsonian Data Management Best Practices has “Five precepts of file naming and organization”

title: Unix/Linux
section: Five Concepts of file naming and organization
text:
Five Concepts of file naming and organization

Have a distinctive, human-readable name that describes the content.
Follow a consistent pattern that is machine-friendly.
Organize files into directories (when necessary) that follow a consistent pattern.
Avoid repetition of semantic elements among file and directory names.
Have a file extension that matches the file format (no changing extensions!)

Tidyverse Style Guide

title: Unix/Linux
text:
The terminal

The terminal is integrated into Mac and Linux systems, but Windows users will have to install an emulator (we will use Git Bash). You may experience it also in Colab.

title: Unix/Linux
text:
File System

The file system is hierarchical, you create directories (folders) in other folders
When you log in to a Unix/Linux computer you are in your home directory
The command line has a prompt that is configurable and let you know that the terminal is ready for input
Environment variables, e.g., $HOME, $PATH, control your computing environment and many are customizable by users

title: Unix/Linux
text: The filesystem

title: Unix/Linux
text:
Files and permissions

within each directory you can create files and other directories
files whose names start with a period . are hidden by default; use ls -a to view them
files have permissions: use ls -lh to view details


drwxr-xr-x    4 robert  staff   128B Aug  8 10:03 bin
-rw-r--r--@   1 robert  staff    20M Jun 24 09:11 boots.png
-rw-r--r--@   1 robert  staff    26M Jun 23 15:23 boots1.pdf


you can read, write, or execute files and control who (Owner, Group, Other) can see or use them by changing permissions

title: Unix/Linux
text:
Working directory

The directory you are currently in.
Commands will generally take effect in this directory
see your working directory using pwd
list the contents of the directory (files and other directories) using ls
find out about how ls works by issuing the command: man ls (long) or ls --help(medium) (shorter version: tldr, whatis, apropos(show me commands relevant to this))

title: Unix/Linux
text:
Paths

The string returned by pwd command is the full path to the working directory.
The full path to your home directory is stored in an environment variable.
You can see it like this echo $HOME

title: Unix/Linux
text:
Paths

the shorthand ~ as a nickname for your home directory

Example: the full path for docs (image in prev. slides) can be written like this ~/docs.

The environment variable called PATH which you can display using echo

that variable is a set of individual paths, separated by : (colon) and it tells your Unix shell where to look for commands
you can add other paths to PATH, so that Unix can look for commands in those paths (eg make your own bin directory)

 https://rafalab.dfci.harvard.edu/dsbook-part-1/productivity/unix.html

ls: Listing directory content
mkdir and rmdir: make and remove a directory
cd: navigating the filesystem by changing directories
pwd: see your workding directory
mv: moving files
cp: copying files
rm: removing files
more and less: display the contents of a file

title: Unix/Linux
text:
Autocomplete

In Unix/Windows you can auto-complete by hitting tab.
Example, if we type cd d then hit tab.
Unix will either auto-complete if docs is the only directory/file starting with d or show you all directories begining with d.

title: Unix/Linux
text:
Other useful commands

curl - download data from the internet.
tar - archive files and directories into one file.
gzip - and other compression tools - make big files small
ssh - connect to another computer.
find - search for files by filename in your system.
grep - search for patterns in a file.
awk/sed - powerful commands to find specific strings in files and change them.

awk: field-based processing (columns, math, conditions)
sed: stream editor (find/replace, delete, rearrange lines)

title: Unix/Linux
text:
A deeper dive

The shell is a program to organize and facilitate your interactions with the operating system
echo $SHELL will display the shell you are using
hidden files and directories to provide customization e.g. .gitconfig or .ssh
most shells have two files that are commonly used to provide user level customization .zsh, and .zprofile

title: Quarto
text:
Computations

By default, the code and result will show up.
You can send arguments to control the behavior with #|
For example, to avoid showing code in the final document, use echo: FALSE.

```{r}
#| echo: false
x <- 1
y <- 2
x + y
```

title: Quarto
text:
Computations

There are many options (auto-complete shows them).
For example, to avoid executing the code use eval: FALSE.
To avoid showing warnings warning: FALSE, to avoid showing messages message: FALSE.







Note


to apply an option globally, these can be set globally in the header.
execute:
  echo: false

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Connect Git and GitHub

When accessing (modifying) GitHub (repo) you need credentials to verify your identity.
There are two ways to connect: HTTPS or SSH, each requiring different credentials.
We recommend using HTTPS, which uses a Personal Access Token (PAT).
Note that your GitHub website password isn’t your access token.

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Connect Git and GitHub

Detailed instructions are here.
Carefully follow the instructions provided by GitHub.
When setting permissions for the token, choose non-expiring and select the repo option in the scopes section.
Once you complete these steps, GitHub will display your token—a lengthy string of characters.
Immediately copy this token to your clipboard. This is the only time GitHub will show it to you.

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Generate a token:

For security, save this token in a password manager. This ensures you can access it if needed later on.
When git prompts you to enter your password, paste the token you’ve copied. After this, password prompts should no longer appear.
If you ever need the token again, retrieve it from your password manager.

More details available from Happy Git and GitHub for the use.

title: Git and GitHub
text:

The next step is to let Git know who we are on Github.
To to this type the following two commands in our terminal window:


git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.mail "your@email.com"

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Connect Git and GitHub

This will change the Git configuration in way that anytime you use Git, it will know this information.
Note that you need to use the email account that you used to open your GitHub account.

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Connect Git and GitHub
To connect working directory to the GitHub repo

initialize the directory:


git init


Let Git know what is the remote repository.


git remote add origin <remote-url>

Now the two are connected.






Note


origin is a nickname we will use for the remote. We can call it something else, but everybody calls it origin so best to stick with that.

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Overview of Git
The main actions in Git are to:

pull changes from the remote repo.
add files, or as we say in the Git lingo stage files.
commit changes to the local repo.
push changes to the remote repo.

title: Git and GitHub
text: The four areas of Git

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Status


git status filename

title: Git and GitHub
Git and GitHub
text:
Commit

To move all the staged files to the local repository we use git commit.



git commit -m "must add comment"


Once committed the files are tracked and a copy of this version is kept going forward.
This is like adding V1 to your filename.

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Commit






Note


You can commit files directly without using add by explicitly writing the files at the end of the commit:




git commit -m "must add comment" <filename>

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Push

To move to upstream repo we use git push



git push -u origin main


The -u flag sets the upstream repo.
By using this flag, going forward you can simply use git push to push changes.
So going forward we can just type:


git push

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Push

When using git push we need to be careful as if collaborating this will affect the work of others.
It might also create a conflict.


Posted by andortang on Nothing is Impossible!

title: Git and GitHub
text:

To update our local repository to the remote one we use


git fetch

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Merge

Once we are sure this is good, we can merge with our local files:


git merge

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Pull

I rarely use fetch and merge and instead use pull which does both of these in one step


git pull

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Checkout

If you want to pull down a specific file you from the remote repo you can use:


git checkout filename


I use this when I make changes but decide I want to go back to original version on remote repo.







Warning


If you have a newer version in your local repository this will create a conflict. It won’t let you do it. If you are sure you want to get rid of your local copy you can remove it and then use checkout.

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Checkout

You can also use checkout to obtain older version:


git checkout <commit-id> <filename>


You can get the commit-id either on the GitHub webpage or using


git log filename

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Reset

What if I commit and realize it was a mistake?


git reset HEAD~1

undos the commit and unstages the files, but keeps your local copies. I use this command very often.

There are many wasy of using get reset and it covers most scenarios.
ChatGPT and stackoverflow are great resources to learn more.

text:

We are just scratching the surface of Git.
One advanced feature to be aware of is that you can have several branches, useful for working in parallel or testing stuff out that might not make the main repo.


Art by: Allison Horst

git remote -v
git branch

Clone

Another common command is git clone.
It let’s download an entire repo, including version history.


git clone <repo-url>

title: Git and GitHub
text:
GitHub Repositories (repo)

You will have at least two copies of your code: one on your computer and one on GitHub.
If you add collaborators to this repo, then each will have a copy on their computer.
The GitHub copy is considered the main (previously called master) copy (branch) that everybody syncs to.
The main branch is the code-base (ground truth).
